title: Parents think son was ‘scammed’ into travelling in refrigerated Essex lorry
text:
Hoang Van Tiep’s family members fear he is among the 39 dead (AP/AFP/Reuters)

The parents of a teenager feared to be among the 39 migrants found dead in a refrigerated lorry in Essex believe their son was scammed into travelling to the UK by truck.

The couple say people traffickers promised Hoang Van Tiep, 18, that he would enter the UK in a four-seater Sedan instead.

As the investigation continues, lorry driver Maurice ‘Mo’ Robinson has been charged with manslaughter and accused of being part of a ‘global ring’ of people smugglers.

Several families have said they’ve paid tens of thousands of pounds for their loved ones to be taken to Britain but were deceived about how they would get there.

Tiep was working in France before deciding to move to the UK to work at a nail salon, against the advice of relatives.

Tiep’s mum Hoang Thi Ai says she would have kept him at home if she knew her son would be travelling by lorry (Picture: AP)

Hoang Thi Nhiem was in tears as she felt ‘guilty’ for not stopping him (Picture: Reuters)

In a video interview, his sister Hoang Thi Nhiem says: ‘I feel guilty towards my brother, I did advise him, I did, but I failed.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘I love my brother Tiep very much. I only hope to hear news from him.

‘Even if the news is that he was arrested by the police, it’s okay too. As long as he’s alive then it’s okay.’

His father Hoang Van Lanh said he didn’t think smugglers meant to kill his son.

He added: ‘It was just unfortunate. I am not mad at anyone, but they told me he will be travelling in a four-seater Sedan.

Ai holds up her phone showing a photo of her missing son (Picture: AP)

Local police gather at the house of 18-year old Tiep (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

Tiep’s father Hoang Lanh didn’t think smugglers intended to kill his son (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

‘I don’t know what kind of vehicle my son ended up in in the end, but that’s what they told us.’

Tiep’s mum Hoang Thi Ai said her son was ‘scammed’ and ‘tricked’ into thinking he would be taken to England under the traffickers’ ‘VIP’ option.

She added: ‘If I had known he would be in a truck I wouldn’t have allowed him to go by keeping him here.’

Ai says she would have told his brothers not to lend him the money needed for the trip.

For many Vietnamese people seeking to embark on the treacherous journey to a new life in Europe, a key question can be: ‘Grass or VIP?’

The going rate to be smuggled from Germany or France to Britain via the higher tier option is around £11,000 per person, according to several migrants, family members and experts.

He was led to believe his son would be taken to the UK in a four-seater Sedan (Picture: Reuters)

Ai says she believes Tiep was the victim of a ‘scam’ (Picture: AFP/Getty Images)

His sister says as long as Tiep is alive, she doesn’t mind what news she gets from him (Picture: AP)

Many Vietnamese people trafficked into the UK end up working in cannabis farms, but ‘grass’ in this context is a Vietnamese slang word to describe something as dirt cheap.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Those taking the cheaper way pay as little as £2,337 to travel overland from Southeast Asia to Europe.

This can mean arduous months of secretive movement by car and even walking.

According to family members, Vietnamese police took hair and blood samples on Sunday to get DNA from relatives of people feared to be among the 39 deceased.

Essex Police initially believed the victims were Chinese nationals but it has since emerged at least 25 could be from Vietnam.

The bodies were found in the early hours of Wednesday, October 23 in a lorry container in an industrial estate in Grays.

A second lorry driver in his 20s was arrested at a port in Dublin on Saturday has also been listed as a ‘person of interest’ in Essex Police’s investigation.

Maurice Robinson has been charged over the 39 bodies were found in the truck he was driving (Picture: Rex Features)

The bodies were found in an industrial estate in Grays, Essex, on Wednesday (Picture: PA)

Tiep was working in France before deciding to travel to the UK to work in a nail salon (Picture: Reuters)

The pair, originally from the Republic of Ireland, were held on suspicion of 39 counts of manslaughter and people trafficking.

A 48-year-old man from Northern Ireland was also taken into custody on Friday at Stansted Airport on suspicion of conspiracy to traffic people and manslaughter.

Advertisement

He has now been released on bail until November 13.

In Belgium, police are hunting the driver who delivered the shipping container to Zeebrugge, the port it left before arriving in the UK.

description: The family of Vietnamese migrant Hoang Van Tiep say he could have been 'scammed' into getting on the lorry carrying 39 dead found in Essex.
